intro: Chamaesyce berteroana, commonly known as the desert sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the family Asteraceae, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble small daisies. The plant typically grows close to the ground, with hairy, succulent leaves that help reduce water loss in hot, dry environments. Its small yellow flowers bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Chamaesyce berteroana is well adapted to sandy soils and can thrive in areas with minimal rainfall.
